member.name: T:System.AppDomain
member.summary: Represents an application domain, which is an isolated environment where applications execute. This class cannot be inherited.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.AppendPrivatePath(System.String)
member.summary: Appends the specified directory name to the private path list.
member.param: The name of the directory to be appended to the private path.
member.exception: The operation is attempted on an unloaded application domain.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.ApplyPolicy(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the assembly display name after policy has been applied.
member.param: The assembly display name, in the form provided by the property.
member.returns: A string containing the assembly display name after policy has been applied.

member.name: E:System.AppDomain.AssemblyLoad
member.summary: Occurs when an assembly is loaded.

member.name: E:System.AppDomain.AssemblyResolve
member.summary: Occurs when the resolution of an assembly fails.

member.name: P:System.AppDomain.BaseDirectory
member.summary: Gets the base directory that the assembly resolver uses to probe for assemblies.
member.returns: The base directory that the assembly resolver uses to probe for assemblies.
member.exception: The operation is attempted on an unloaded application domain.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.ClearPrivatePath
member.summary: Resets the path that specifies the location of private assemblies to the empty string ("").
member.exception: The operation is attempted on an unloaded application domain.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.ClearShadowCopyPath
member.summary: Resets the list of directories containing shadow copied assemblies to the empty string ("").
member.exception: The operation is attempted on an unloaded application domain.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.CreateDomain(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new application domain with the specified name.
member.param: The friendly name of the domain.
member.returns: The newly created application domain.
member.exception: is .
Method not supported on .NET Core.

member.name: M:System.AppDomain.CreateInstance(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Reflection.BindingFlags,System.Reflection.Binder,System.Object[],System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the specified type defined in the specified assembly. Parameters specify a binder, binding flags, constructor arguments, culture-specific information used to interpret arguments, and optional activation attributes.
member.param: The display name of the assembly. See .
The fully qualified name of the requested type, including the namespace but not the assembly, as returned by the property.
A Boolean value specifying whether to perform a case-sensitive search or not.
A combination of zero or more bit flags that affect the search for the constructor. If is zero, a case-sensitive search for public constructors is conducted.
An object that enables the binding, coercion of argument types, invocation of members, and retrieval of objects using reflection. If is null, the default binder is used.

The arguments to pass to the constructor. This array of arguments must match in number, order, and type the parameters of the constructor to invoke. If the parameterless constructor is preferred, must be an empty array or null.
Culture-specific information that governs the coercion of to the formal types declared for the constructor. If is , the for the current thread is used.

An array of one or more attributes that can participate in activation. Typically, an array that contains a single object that specifies the URL that is required to activate a remote object. This parameter is related to client-activated objects. Client activation is a legacy technology that is retained for backward compatibility but is not recommended for new development. Distributed applications should instead use Windows Communication Foundation.
member.returns: An object that is a wrapper for the new instance specified by . The return value needs to be unwrapped to access the real object.
member.exception: The operation is attempted on an unloaded application domain.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch
member.summary: Provides a set of methods and properties that you can use to accurately measure elapsed time.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Elapsed
member.summary: Gets the total elapsed time measured by the current instance.
member.returns: A read-only representing the total elapsed time measured by the current instance.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets the total elapsed time measured by the current instance, in milliseconds.
member.returns: A read-only long integer representing the total number of milliseconds measured by the current instance.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.ElapsedTicks
member.summary: Gets the total elapsed time measured by the current instance, in timer ticks.
member.returns: A read-only long integer representing the total number of timer ticks measured by the current instance.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Frequency
member.summary: Gets the frequency of the timer as the number of ticks per second. This field is read-only.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.GetTimestamp
member.summary: Gets the current number of ticks in the timer mechanism.
member.returns: A long integer representing the tick counter value of the underlying timer mechanism.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.IsHighResolution
member.summary: Indicates whether the timer is based on a high-resolution performance counter. This field is read-only.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.IsRunning
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the timer is running.
member.returns: if the instance is currently running and measuring elapsed time for an interval; otherwise, .

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Reset
member.summary: Stops time interval measurement and resets the elapsed time to zero.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Restart
member.summary: Stops time interval measurement, resets the elapsed time to zero, and starts measuring elapsed time.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Start
member.summary: Starts, or resumes, measuring elapsed time for an interval.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.StartNew
member.summary: Initializes a new instance, sets the elapsed time property to zero, and starts measuring elapsed time.
member.returns: A that has just begun measuring elapsed time.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch.Stop
member.summary: Stops measuring elapsed time for an interval.

member.name: T:System.Environment
member.summary: Provides information about, and means to manipulate, the current environment and platform. This class cannot be inherited.

member.name: P:System.Environment.CommandLine
member.summary: Gets the command line for this process.
member.returns: A string containing command-line arguments.

member.name: P:System.Environment.CurrentDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the fully qualified path of the current working directory.
member.returns: A string containing a directory path.
member.exception: Attempted to set to an empty string ("").
Attempted to set to
An I/O error occurred.
Attempted to set a local path that cannot be found.
The caller does not have the appropriate permission.

member.name: P:System.Environment.CurrentManagedThreadId
member.summary: Gets a unique identifier for the current managed thread.
member.returns: An integer that represents a unique identifier for this managed thread.

member.name: M:System.Environment.Exit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Terminates this process and returns an exit code to the operating system.
member.param: The exit code to return to the operating system. Use 0 (zero) to indicate that the process completed successfully.
member.exception: The caller does not have sufficient security permission to perform this function.

member.name: P:System.Environment.ExitCode
member.summary: Gets or sets the exit code of the process.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer containing the exit code. The default value is 0 (zero), which indicates that the process completed successfully.

member.name: M:System.Environment.ExpandEnvironmentVariables(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the name of each environment variable embedded in the specified string with the string equivalent of the value of the variable, then returns the resulting string.
member.param: A string containing the names of zero or more environment variables. Each environment variable is quoted with the percent sign character (%).
member.returns: A string with each environment variable replaced by its value.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:System.Environment.FailFast(System.String)
member.summary: Immediately terminates a process after writing a message to the Windows Application event log, and then includes the message in error reporting to Microsoft.
member.param: A message that explains why the process was terminated, or if no explanation is provided.

member.name: M:System.Environment.FailFast(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Immediately terminates a process after writing a message to the Windows Application event log, and then includes the message and exception information in error reporting to Microsoft.
member.param: A message that explains why the process was terminated, or if no explanation is provided.
An exception that represents the error that caused the termination. This is typically the exception in a block.

member.name: M:System.Environment.GetCommandLineArgs
member.summary: Returns a string array containing the command-line arguments for the current process.
member.returns: An array of string where each element contains a command-line argument. The first element is the executable file name, and the following zero or more elements contain the remaining command-line arguments.
member.exception: The system does not support command-line arguments.

member.name: T:System.Environment.SpecialFolder
member.summary: Specifies enumerated constants used to retrieve directory paths to system special folders.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.AdminTools
member.summary: The file system directory that is used to store administrative tools for an individual user. The Microsoft Management Console (MMC) will save customized consoles to this directory, and it will roam with the user. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.ApplicationData
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for application-specific data for the current roaming user. A roaming user works on more than one computer on a network. A roaming user's profile is kept on a server on the network and is loaded onto a system when the user logs on.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CDBurning
member.summary: The file system directory that acts as a staging area for files waiting to be written to a CD. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonAdminTools
member.summary: The file system directory that contains administrative tools for all users of the computer. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonApplicationData
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for application-specific data that is used by all users.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonDesktopDirectory
member.summary: The file system directory that contains files and folders that appear on the desktop for all users. This special folder is valid only for Windows NT systems. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonDocuments
member.summary: The file system directory that contains documents that are common to all users. This special folder is valid for Windows NT systems, Windows 95, and Windows 98 systems with Shfolder.dll installed. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonMusic
member.summary: The file system directory that serves as a repository for music files common to all users. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonOemLinks
member.summary: This value is recognized in Windows Vista for backward compatibility, but the special folder itself is no longer used. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonPictures
member.summary: The file system directory that serves as a repository for image files common to all users. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonProgramFiles
member.summary: The directory for components that are shared across applications. To get the x86 common program files directory on a non-x86 system, use the member.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonProgramFilesX86
member.summary: The Program Files folder. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonPrograms
member.summary: A folder for components that are shared across applications. This special folder is valid only for Windows NT, Windows 2000, and Windows XP systems. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonStartMenu
member.summary: The file system directory that contains the programs and folders that appear on the Start menu for all users. This special folder is valid only for Windows NT systems. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonStartup
member.summary: The file system directory that contains the programs that appear in the Startup folder for all users. This special folder is valid only for Windows NT systems. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonTemplates
member.summary: The file system directory that contains the templates that are available to all users. This special folder is valid only for Windows NT systems. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.CommonVideos
member.summary: The file system directory that serves as a repository for video files common to all users. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.Cookies
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for Internet cookies.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.Desktop
member.summary: The logical Desktop rather than the physical file system location.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.DesktopDirectory
member.summary: The directory used to physically store file objects on the desktop. Do not confuse this directory with the desktop folder itself, which is a virtual folder.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.Favorites
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for the user's favorite items.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.Fonts
member.summary: A virtual folder that contains fonts. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.History
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for Internet history items.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.InternetCache
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for temporary Internet files.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.LocalApplicationData
member.summary: The directory that serves as a common repository for application-specific data that is used by the current, non-roaming user.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.LocalizedResources
member.summary: The file system directory that contains localized resource data. Added in the .NET Framework 4.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.MyComputer
member.summary: The My Computer folder. When passed to the method, the enumeration member always yields the empty string ("") because no path is defined for the My Computer folder.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.MyDocuments
member.summary: The My Documents folder. This member is equivalent to .

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolder.MyMusic
member.summary: The My Music folder.

member.summary: The path to the folder is returned without verifying whether the path exists. If the folder is located on a network, specifying this option can reduce lag time.

member.name: F:System.Environment.SpecialFolderOption.None
member.summary: The path to the folder is verified. If the folder exists, the path is returned. If the folder does not exist, an empty string is returned. This is the default behavior.

member.name: T:System.LoaderOptimization
member.summary: An enumeration used with the class to specify loader optimizations for an executable.

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.DisallowBindings
member.summary: Ignored by the common language runtime.

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.DomainMask
member.summary: Do not use. This mask selects the domain-related values, screening out the unused flag.

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.MultiDomain
member.summary: Indicates that the application will probably have many domains that use the same code, and the loader must share maximal internal resources across application domains.

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.MultiDomainHost
member.summary: Indicates that the application will probably host unique code in multiple domains, and the loader must share resources across application domains only for globally available (strong-named) assemblies that have been added to the global assembly cache.

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.NotSpecified
member.summary: Indicates that no optimizations for sharing internal resources are specified. If the default domain or hosting interface specified an optimization, then the loader uses that; otherwise, the loader uses .

member.name: F:System.LoaderOptimization.SingleDomain
member.summary: Indicates that the application will probably have a single domain, and loader must not share internal resources across application domains.

member.name: T:System.LoaderOptimizationAttribute
member.summary: Used to set the default loader optimization policy for the main method of an executable application.

member.returns: An angle, θ, measured in radians, such that -π/2 ≤θ≤π/2. -or- if equals , -π/2 rounded to double precision (-1.5707963267949) if equals , or π/2 rounded to double precision (1.5707963267949) if equals .

member.name: M:System.Math.Atan2(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose tangent is the quotient of two specified numbers.
member.param: The y coordinate of a point.
The x coordinate of a point.
member.returns:
An angle, θ, measured in radians, such that -π≤θ≤π, and tan(θ) = / , where (, ) is a point in the Cartesian plane. Observe the following:
For (, ) in quadrant 1, 0 < θ < π/2.
For (, ) in quadrant 2, π/2 < θ≤π.
For (, ) in quadrant 3, -π < θ < -π/2.
For (, ) in quadrant 4, -π/2 < θ < 0.
For points on the boundaries of the quadrants, the return value is the following:
If y is 0 and x is not negative, θ = 0.
If y is 0 and x is negative, θ = π.
If y is positive and x is 0, θ = π/2.
If y is negative and x is 0, θ = -π/2.
If y is 0 and x is 0, θ = 0.
If or is , or if and are either or , the method returns .

member.name: M:System.Math.Atanh(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose hyperbolic tangent is the specified number.
member.param: A number representing a hyperbolic tangent, where must be greater than or equal to -1, but less than or equal to 1.
member.returns: An angle, θ, measured in radians, such that -∞ < θ < -1, or 1 < θ < ∞. -or- if < -1 or > 1 or equals .

member.name: M:System.MathF.Atan2(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose tangent is the quotient of two specified numbers.
member.param: The y coordinate of a point.
The x coordinate of a point.
member.returns:
An angle, θ, measured in radians, such that -π ≤ θ ≤ π, and tan(θ) = / , where (, ) is a point in the Cartesian plane. Observe the following:
For (, ) in quadrant 1, 0 < θ < π/2.
For (, ) in quadrant 2, π/2 < θ ≤ π.
For (, ) in quadrant 3, -π < θ < -π/2.
For (, ) in quadrant 4, -π/2 < θ < 0.
For points on the boundaries of the quadrants, the return value is the following:
If y is 0 and x is not negative, θ = 0.
If y is 0 and x is negative, θ = π.
If y is positive and x is 0, θ = π/2.
If y is negative and x is 0, θ = -π/2.
If y is 0 and x is 0, θ = 0.
If or is , or if and are either or , the method returns .

member.summary: Gets a value that indicates the guaranteed level of compatibility of a library, type, or type member that spans multiple versions.
member.returns: One of the enumeration values that specifies the level of compatibility that is guaranteed across multiple versions.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.ComponentGuaranteesOptions
member.summary: Describes the compatibility guarantee of a component, type, or type member that may span multiple versions.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Versioning.ComponentGuaranteesOptions.Exchange
member.summary: The developer promises multi-version exchange compatibility for the type. Consumers of the type can expect compatibility across future versions and can use the type in all their interfaces. Versioning problems cannot be fixed by side-by-side execution.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Versioning.ComponentGuaranteesOptions.None
member.summary: The developer does not guarantee compatibility across versions. Consumers of the component, type, or member can expect future versions to break the existing client.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Versioning.ComponentGuaranteesOptions.SideBySide
member.summary: The component has been tested to work when more than one version of the assembly is loaded into the same application domain. Future versions can break compatibility. However, when such breaking changes are made, the old version is not modified but continues to exist alongside the new version.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.Versioning.ComponentGuaranteesOptions.Stable
member.summary: The developer promises stable compatibility across versions. Consumers of the type can expect that future versions will not break the existing client. However, if they do and if the client has not used the type in its interfaces, side-by-side execution may fix the problem.

member.summary: Ability to view and modify policy. This is a powerful permission that should only be granted to highly trusted code.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.ControlPrincipal
member.summary: Ability to manipulate the principal object.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.ControlThread
member.summary: Ability to use certain advanced operations on threads.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.Execution
member.summary: Permission for the code to run. Without this permission, managed code will not be executed. This flag has no effect when used dynamically with stack modifiers such as , , and .

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.Infrastructure
member.summary: Permission to plug code into the common language runtime infrastructure, such as adding Remoting Context Sinks, Envoy Sinks and Dynamic Sinks.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.NoFlags
member.summary: No security access.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.RemotingConfiguration
member.summary: Permission to configure Remoting types and channels.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.SerializationFormatter
member.summary: Ability to provide serialization services. Used by serialization formatters.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.SkipVerification
member.summary: Ability to skip verification of code in this assembly. Code that is unverifiable can be run if this permission is granted. This is a powerful permission that should be granted only to highly trusted code. This flag has no effect when used dynamically with stack modifiers such as , , and .

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionFlag.UnmanagedCode
member.summary: Ability to call unmanaged code. Since unmanaged code potentially allows other permissions to be bypassed, this is a dangerous permission that should only be granted to highly trusted code. It is used for such applications as calling native code using PInvoke or using COM interop.
